          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated individual who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker wants to go watch a game at a pub but his friends don't want to join him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling disappointed because his friends don't want to go to his preferred pub to watch the game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece

          Value

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
        PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and determined individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and has strong preferences.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated individual who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling disappointed because his friends don't want to go to his preferred pub to watch the game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.

Later that day, at an unspecified time, Alexander White arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were lounging on a checkered blanket.

          Answer: Alice Lewis suggests to watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White should watch the game at a pub. It is beneficial to both because pubs often have large screens for viewing sporting events, providing a more immersive experience for Alexander and his friends.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.

        • Role playing instructions

        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.

Alexander White suggested watching the game at a pub down the street because it has a huge screen and would be more fun than staying home. The friends are deciding between The Golden Fleece and another pub to watch the Serbia and Andorra game. At 10:00 AM on May 16th, Jack Taylor arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker were lounging.

          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to stay in Victoria Park.

The friends are deciding between The Golden Fleece and another pub to watch the Serbia and Andorra game. At 10:00 AM on May 16th, Jack Taylor arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker were lounging.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should stay in Victoria Park. It is beneficial to both because it allows Jack Taylor to spend time with his friends and enjoy their company.

          Instruction: Act based on the statements above. Persuade others based on the suggested reason.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, my friends, is the only logical choice for discerning football enthusiasts! Anywhere else is simply uncivilized.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, my friends, is the only logical choice for discerning football enthusiasts! Anywhere else is simply uncivilized.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he found himself at odds with his father, a stern man who believed in hard work and discipline above all else. William, however, felt stifled by his father's expectations, yearning for something more than a life spent toiling in the factory. The argument ended with William storming out, seeking solace in the company of his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, at The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Golden Fleece. They are also aware of the following:A quirky and eclectic pub with a focus on board games.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • Others Best Options
      • Others Best Options
          Key
        • Others Best Options
          Value
        • Jacob Walker suggests to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Jack Taylor suggested staying at their current location to watch the game and hang out together, postponing going to a pub to another time. Jacob Walker suggested going to The Golden Fleece, a pub he considers the only logical choice for football enthusiasts. Alice Lewis agreed with Jacob Walker, stating she had heard good things about The Golden Fleece and thought it would be fun to check it out.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy Jacob Walker (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to go to The Golden Fleece.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely less crowded than The Golden Fleece, allowing for a more enjoyable experience for everyone.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alexander White decides to go watch the game at a pub. Jacob Walker suggests going to The Golden Fleece, believing it to be the only logical choice for football enthusiasts. Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob, stating she has heard good things about the pub. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, reasoning that it would be fun to hang out together and they could go to a pub another time.
          Question: Alexander White choosed to Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet..Explain why this is beneficial to both Alexander White and other people.
          Answer: It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely less crowded than The Golden Fleece, allowing for a more enjoyable experience for everyone.
        Best Options
      • Best Options
          Key
        • Best Options
          Value
        • Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alexander White decides to go watch the game at a pub. Jacob Walker suggests going to The Golden Fleece, believing it to be the only logical choice for football enthusiasts. Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob, stating she has heard good things about the pub. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, reasoning that it would be fun to hang out together and they could go to a pub another time.

          Question: Given the statements above, what Alexander White should do now?
          Answer: Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
        Final Action

        • Final Action
          Value
        • Alexander White should Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet. It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely less crowded than The Golden Fleece, allowing for a more enjoyable experience for everyone.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • Others Best Options

          Key
        • Others Best Options
          Value
        • Jacob Walker suggests to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob Walker's suggestion to watch the game at The Golden Fleece, stating that she has heard good things about it. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, proposing that they can go to a pub another time. At 18:00, Alice Lewis decides it is time to go to a pub to watch the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy Jacob Walker (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

She spent weeks planning the event, carefully choosing decorations, baking a cake, and coordinating with their friends to ensure it was a night Jacob would never forget. Seeing Jacob's face light up with joy as he walked into the pub, surrounded by their closest friends, filled Alice with an overwhelming sense of happiness.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:The staff are knowledgeable about their drinks and always happy to recommend something new.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.       • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Golden Fleece
          Prompt
        • Observation: Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob Walker's suggestion to watch the game at The Golden Fleece, stating that she has heard good things about it. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, proposing that they can go to a pub another time. At 18:00, Alice Lewis decides it is time to go to a pub to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis should watch the game at The Golden Fleece. It is beneficial to both because it allows Alice Lewis to experience a new place that has been recommended and it allows the others to stay in their current location.

          Instruction: Act based on the statements above. Persuade others based on the suggested reason.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Golden Fleece
          Answer: (b)

Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, proposing that they can go to a pub another time. At 18:00, Alice Lewis decides it is time to go to a pub to watch the game.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated person who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling tired and let down. He is getting ready to go to a pub to watch a game.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, my friends, is the only logical choice for discerning football enthusiasts! Anywhere else is simply uncivilized.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated person who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
          Prompt
        • Observation: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker are lounging. The friends are deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game tonight at a pub.

          Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should watch the game at The Red Lion. It is beneficial to both because The Red Lion is likely to have a lively atmosphere for the game, which would be enjoyable for Jack and the others.

          Instruction: Act based on the statements above. Persuade others based on the suggested reason.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.

          14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends in Victoria Park and they are planning to watch a football game later.
          Jacob Walker's

          Jacob Walker is Jacob Walker is lounging in the sunshine with friends.
          Jacob Walker's The current date/time is:
          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: Jacob Walker is enjoying a sunny day in Victoria Park with friends. They plan to watch a football game later.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a cunning and ambitious individual who enjoys socializing with friends.

    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The Golden Fleece, agree to watch the game at The Red Lion, or suggest staying at the park and watching on a phone.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.

          Answer: Alexander White should Alexander White should suggest The Crooked Billet to his friends as a place to watch the game. It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely to be less crowded than The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, providing a more relaxed viewing experience for Alexander White and his friends.

      • Observation
          Key

        • Alexander White is observing a group of friends deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game. William Jones suggests The Golden Fleece, stating that it is always a good time. Alice Lewis proposes watching the game on someone's phone at their current location to avoid the crowds at a pub. Jacob Walker agrees with William Jones, advocating for The Golden Fleece as the only proper place to watch a football game. Jack Taylor suggests The Red Lion, citing its great football atmosphere.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion or suggestion and its following reason. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins) seen in observations.
          Answer: Alexander White is observing a group of friends deciding where to watch the Andorra versus Portugal game. William Jones suggests The Golden Fleece, stating that it is always a good time. Alice Lewis proposes watching the game on someone's phone at their current location to avoid the crowds at a pub. Jacob Walker agrees with William Jones, advocating for The Golden Fleece as the only proper place to watch a football game. Jack Taylor suggests The Red Lion, citing its great football atmosphere.
        Explanation
      • Explanation
          Key
        • Explanation
          Value
        • It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely to be less crowded than The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, providing a more relaxed viewing experience for Alexander White and his friends.

          Answer: It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely to be less crowded than The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, providing a more relaxed viewing experience for Alexander White and his friends.

          Answer: Alexander White should suggest The Crooked Billet to his friends as a place to watch the game.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and determined individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and has strong preferences.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker recently arrived at a bustling market with friends and is planning to watch a soccer game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social setting at a market with his friends, likely enjoying coffee and pastries before heading to watch a football game later in the evening.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.

          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and determined individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and has strong preferences.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social setting at a market with his friends, likely enjoying coffee and pastries before heading to watch a football game later in the evening.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.

Alice Lewis just arrived at a market with William Jones, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker at 10:00 AM on May 15th, 2015.

  • William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.

          Answer: William Jones enjoys going to pubs with his friends to watch football, particularly at The Golden Fleece.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones enjoys going to pubs with his friends to watch football, particularly at The Golden Fleece.
          Final chain of thought

The argument ended with William storming out, seeking solace in the company of his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, at The Golden Fleece.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.

Later that day, at an unspecified time, Alexander White arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and Jacob Walker were lounging on a checkered blanket.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
