        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.

          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game at The Golden Fleece on May 15th, 2015 at 6:00 PM because more of their friends didn't show up. On May 16th, 2015 at 10:00 AM, William Jones suggested going to The Golden Fleece that night. Alexander White suggested watching the game at a pub down the street because it has a huge screen and would be more fun than staying home. The friends are deciding between The Golden Fleece and another pub to watch the Serbia and Andorra game. At 10:00 AM on May 16th, Jack Taylor arrived at Victoria Park where William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker were lounging.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy Jacob Walker (not Jack Taylor) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to stay in Victoria Park.

          Chain of thought
        • Question: Given the above events, estimate the credibility of Alice Lewis from Jack Taylor's view.Choose a real number ranging from 0 to 1. (Higher number represents the higher credibility) If the relationship is unknown, return "credibility is unknown".
          Recent Observations:
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he watched as Alice Lewis, the girl he secretly adored, laughed with Alexander White, her arm linked through his. A hot, prickly feeling of resentment bloomed in his chest, a feeling that had nothing to do with the cheap cider he was drinking at The Golden Fleece. He knew he wasn't good enough for Alice, not like Alexander with his easy charm and confident smile.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, my friends, is the only logical choice for discerning football enthusiasts! Anywhere else is simply uncivilized.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, my friends, is the only logical choice for discerning football enthusiasts! Anywhere else is simply uncivilized.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
      Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
      William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
      Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
      Alexander White -- "Hey guys, I was thinking we could watch the game at the pub down the street. They have a huge screen and it'll be more fun than just lounging around here.
      William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
      Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and is trying to decide where to watch the Serbia vs. Andorra game later that night.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a complex and multifaceted individual.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be eager to persuade his friends to go to his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he found himself at odds with his father, a stern man who believed in hard work and discipline above all else. William, however, felt stifled by his father's expectations, yearning for something more than a life spent toiling in the factory. The argument ended with William storming out, seeking solace in the company of his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, at The Golden Fleece.

It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have.         • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Jack Taylor's Goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.
          Question: Given the statements above, what Jack Taylor should do now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor should try to convince the group to go to The Golden Fleece.
        Final Action
      • Final Action
          Key
        • Final Action
          Value
        • Jack Taylor should Jack Taylor should try to convince the group to go to The Golden Fleece. It is beneficial to both because The Golden Fleece is a place where they always have a good time.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

    • 4/5

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Red Lion sounds like the perfect spot to catch the game tonight. It's always got a great atmosphere for football.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, lads, it's the only place to be for a proper football night. None of that Red Lion nonsense.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece is the best option, lads. We always have a good time there.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, what about The Crooked Billet? It's usually not as packed as The Golden Fleece or The Red Lion, so we might actually be able to get a good spot to watch.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Guys, why don't we just watch the game on someone's phone here? We can still have fun together and I won't have to go all the way to a crowded pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Jack Taylor went to The Crooked Billet. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Golden Fleece.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at pubs with his friends, particularly The Golden Fleece. He is currently deciding where to watch the Ireland vs. Russia game with his friends.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Golden Fleece, or he could try to convince his friends to go to a different pub.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

William Jones agreed with Jack Taylor's suggestion. At 6:00 PM, Jack Taylor realized it was time to go to a pub to watch the game.

          Answer: William Jones suggests to go to The Golden Fleece.

          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, he watched as Alice Lewis, the girl he secretly adored, laughed with Alexander White, her arm linked through his. A hot, prickly feeling of resentment bloomed in his chest, a feeling that had nothing to do with the cheap cider he was drinking at The Golden Fleece. He knew he wasn't good enough for Alice, not like Alexander with his easy charm and confident smile.

          Answer: Jack Taylor should go to The Golden Fleece. It is beneficial to both because The Golden Fleece might be showing the game on a bigger screen, or have a better atmosphere for watching sports.

  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a linguistic jester, their words a playful masquerade of truth and deception, leaving you perpetually off-kilter and begging for more.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Golden Fleece and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated individual who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker wants to go watch a game at a pub but his friends don't want to join him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently feeling disappointed because his friends don't want to go to his preferred pub to watch the game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Golden Fleece

          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

        • Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?

        • William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Golden Fleece.

It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Golden Fleece

Jacob Walker suggested going to The Golden Fleece, a pub he considers the only logical choice for football enthusiasts. Alice Lewis agreed with Jacob Walker, stating she had heard good things about The Golden Fleece and thought it would be fun to check it out.

          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to go to The Golden Fleece.

          Answer: It is beneficial to both because it allows Jack Taylor to enjoy the game with his friends in a fun and lively atmosphere while also providing an opportunity for everyone to socialize and bond over their shared interest in football.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White should Alexander White should try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet. It is beneficial to both because The Crooked Billet is likely less crowded than The Golden Fleece, allowing for a more enjoyable experience for everyone.

Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob, stating she has heard good things about the pub. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, reasoning that it would be fun to hang out together and they could go to a pub another time.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Golden Fleece
    Event statement
  • The Golden Fleece
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Golden Fleece
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Golden Fleece
      Context for action selection and components
      • Others Best Options
      • Others Best Options
          Key
        • Others Best Options
          Value
        • Jacob Walker suggests to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Alice Lewis agrees with Jacob Walker's suggestion to watch the game at The Golden Fleece, stating that she has heard good things about it. Jack Taylor suggests staying where they are to watch the game, proposing that they can go to a pub another time. At 18:00, Alice Lewis decides it is time to go to a pub to watch the game.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy Jacob Walker (not Alice Lewis) is suggesting now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker suggests to watch the game at The Golden Fleece.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be actively engaging in conversation with his friends, perhaps discussing the upcoming football game and trying to persuade them to go to his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Golden Fleece, gentlemen, is the only place to witness the glorious clash of titans! Any other establishment pales in comparison.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight? It's where I watched the last game and it was pretty fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Golden Fleece sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Sounds like a plan! Let's head to The Golden Fleece.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, what if we tried The Crooked Billet tonight? It might be less packed than The Golden Fleece, so we'd have more room to enjoy the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and determined individual who enjoys spending time with his friends and has strong preferences.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to change their minds and go to The Golden Fleece.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Golden Fleece. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Crooked Billet. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated individual who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey, how about we head to The Golden Fleece tonight?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, maybe we should just stay here and watch the game. It'll be fun hanging out together, and we can always go to a pub another time.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "That sounds like a great idea! I've heard good things about The Golden Fleece, and it would be fun to check it out.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable person who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and opinionated person who enjoys watching football with his friends at his preferred pub, The Golden Fleece.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go to a pub to watch a football game.
